GLdouble frustum [6]

Detailed Description

A class that acts as a camera.

Largely, this class is a wrapper for calls to gluLookAt(). However, it has a few advantages, with more in the works. Aside from simply setting the location of the camera, the location it looks at, and the direction which is 'up', this class has members to rotate the camera by some angle as though it were on the surface of a sphere. In the future, we will include functions to use DeltaFunctors to set a path in three dimensional space for the camera to follow, allowing for pre-defined complex camera motions. In addition, we will create functions which are essentially the reverse of the current spherical functions, where the point that you are looking at can be adjusted as though it were on the surface of a sphere centered at the eye. This is similar to a FPS type camera mode.

Todo:
Set up a function to use DeltaFunctors as a path for the camera.
Todo:
Create functions which move the lookAtPosition as though on the surface of a sphere.
Todo:
Build an FPS mode.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

Camera::Camera (  ) 

The default constructor for the camera class.

By default the following are set:

  • eyePosition = <0, 0, 1>,
  • lookAtPosition = <0, 0, 0>,
  • upDirection = <1, 0, 0>,
  • frustum[] = {-1, 1, -1, 1, 2, 100},
  • angleLeftFunct = NULL,
  • angleUpFunct = NULL.

void Camera::setFrustum ( GLdouble  left,
GLdouble  right,
GLdouble  bottom,
GLdouble  top,
GLdouble  zNear,
GLdouble  zFar 
)

Set the viewing frustum.

A recommended call would be as follows (width/height are the width and height of the window):

myCamera->setFrustum(-width/height, width/height, -1, 1, 2, 100);

Parameters:
left is the left edge of the viewing frustum
right is the right edge of the viewing frustum
bottom is the bottom edge of the viewing frustum
top is the top edge of the viewing frustum
zNear is the distance to the nearest clipping plane, must be greater than 0
zFar is the distance to the farthest clipping plane, must be greater than zNear
See also:
frustum[]

00148     frustum[5] = zFar;

void Camera::update (  ) 

Update the camera.

This function updates the projection matrix so that it includes the camera at its current position, direction, etc. Should be called before each frame is rendered.

Don't update the frustrum, or the up direction but the look at needs to be 1 in front of the character (relative to rotational coords) and the x/y/z need to be the middle of the character (or whatever its reporting)

Todo:
fix the camera so that character actually does a reasonable view so that it works

void Camera::spinRightAroundCenter ( GLdouble  angle  ) 

Spin right or left.

SpinRightAroundCenter moves (as you would expect) to the right, from the perspective of the viewer, a though the camera were on the surface of a sphere centered at lookAtPosition. Makes no changes to lookAtPosition or upDirection, but does adjust eyePosition. Positive values of angle move right, negative move left.

This function is a part of the spin***AroundCenter() group of functions in which motion acts as though the camera is on the surface of a sphere centered at lookAtPosition.

Parameters:
angle is the angle in degrees that you wish to rotate by
See also:
lookAtPosition

upDirection

eyePosition

spinUpAroundCenter()

spinViewAroundCenter()

Definition at line 202 of file camera.cpp.

00202                                                  {
00203     double radius = (eyePosition - lookAtPosition).getMag();
00204 
00205     //Set up some basis vectors for the plane in which you want to move
00206     Point3 basisY = (eyePosition - lookAtPosition).getUnit();
00207     Point3 basisX = Point3::cross(basisY, upDirection).getUnit();
00208 
00209     //Rotate the basis vectors by angle, this is the vector to translate
00210     //to our final destination
00211     Point3 returnVector = basisX*cos((angle+90)*(PI/180.0)) + basisY*sin((angle+90)*(PI/180.0));
00212 
00213     //Translate to the final position
00214     eyePosition = lookAtPosition + returnVector.getUnit()*radius;
00215 }

void Camera::spinUpAroundCenter ( GLdouble  angle  ) 

Spin up or down.

This spins you in the up direction, from the perspective of the viewer, as though on the surface of a sphere centered at lookAtPosition. This function will not change lookAtPosition, but will adjust both upDirection and eyePosition. Positive values of angle move up, negative values move down.

This function is a part of the spin***AroundCenter() group of functions in which motion acts as though the camera is on the surface of a sphere centered at lookAtPosition.

Parameters:
angle is the angle in degrees that you wish to spin.
See also:
lookAtPosition

upDirection

eyePosition

spinRightAroundCenter()

spinViewAroundCenter()

00240     Point3 basisY = (eyePosition - lookAtPosition).getUnit();
00241     Point3 basisX = Point3::cross(basisY, upDirection).getUnit();
00242     Point3 basisZ = Point3::cross(basisX, basisY).getUnit();
00243 
00244     //Rotate the basis vectors by angle, this is the vector to translate
00245     //to our final destination
00246     Point3 returnVector = basisY*cos((angle)*(PI/180.0)) + basisZ*sin((angle)*(PI/180.0));
00247 
00248     //Adjust the upDirection
00249     upDirection = basisZ;
00250 
00251     //Translate to the final position
00252     eyePosition = lookAtPosition + returnVector.getUnit()*radius;
00253 }

void Camera::spinViewAroundCenter ( GLdouble  angle  ) 

Rotates the camera.

This rotates the apparent view of the camera in the counter- clockwise direction. Really just changing the upDirection vector, makes no changes to lookAtPosition or eyePosition. Positive values of angle are CCW, negative are CW.

This function is a part of the spin***AroundCenter() group of functions in which motion acts as though the camera is on the surface of a sphere centered at lookAtPosition.

Parameters:
angle is The angle in degrees you wish to spin
See also:
lookAtPosition

upDirection

void Camera::zoomIn ( GLdouble  amount  ) 

Zoom in/out.

Zoom the camera in or out, depending on value of amount. Values less than one will zoom in, values greater than one will zoom out. Reciprocals will zoom in/out equal amounts, so that zoomIn(3) followed by zoomIn(1.0/3.0) will result in no movement at all. This function only adjusts the value of eyePosition.

Parameters:
amount is the zoom scalar
See also:
eyePosition

Definition at line 316 of file camera.cpp.

00316                                    {
00317     eyePosition = eyePosition * amount;
00318 }

void Camera::shift ( Point3  direction,
GLdouble  amount 
)

Shift the camera.

Shift the camera in some direction by some amount. Does not change the direction that you are looking, or the upDirection. Will, however, change eyePosition and lookAtPosition.

Parameters:
direction is a vector pointing in the direction of the shift
amount is the distance of the shift
See also:

Definition at line 43 of file camera.h.

GLdouble Camera::frustum[6] [private]

Contains the coordinates for a frustum.

This is all of the pieces that you would put into a normal gluLookAt() call. The first two elements are the left and right coordinates of the viewing plane. The second two elements are the bottom and top coordinates of the viewing plane. The last two elements are the distances to the near and far clipping planes. Note that 0 < frustum[4] < frustum[5], else there are problems. A fairly standard setup would be as follows (width and height are the width and height of your window):

frustum[] = {-width/height, width/height, -1, 1, 2, 100}

See also:
setFrustum()
